# Advertising / Sales Copy Framework

## Overview
This framework applies 12 proven copywriting rules specifically for AI automation services, targeting business owners who want to save time and aspiring entrepreneurs who want to sell automation services. All examples maintain a practical, no-nonsense tone without hype or exaggeration.

---

## Rule 1: Headlines Come First for a Reason
**Principle:** Your headline determines if people read anything else. It's 80% of your advertising effectiveness.

### Examples for AI Automation:

**Ad Headlines:**
- "Built a System That Handles 15,000 Orders. Here's How."
- "The Exact Templates We Used at Dishpatch (Now Yours)"
- "From Manual Chaos to Automated Calm: A Practical Guide"

**Conversion Page Headlines:**
- "From Zero to First Automation in 7 Days - Even If YouTube Tutorials Left You Confused"
- "Stop Watching Random Tutorials. Start Building Real Business Systems."
- "Copy-Paste Templates That Actually Work (Because We Built Them for Real Clients)"

**About Page Headlines:**
- "From 100 to 15,000 Deliveries: Why I'm Obsessed with Systems That Scale"
- "I've Taught 100,000+ People, But the Systems Still Have to Work"

---

## Rule 2: Say What Only You Can Say
**Principle:** Your unique proof can't be copied by competitors.

### Examples for AI Automation:

**Ad Copy:**
"100,000+ people have learned automation from my content. 26k YouTube subscribers. 4.6/5 on Udemy. I focus entirely on teaching now because that's where I make the biggest impact - helping others build what took me years to figure out."

**Conversion Page:**
"After scaling a startup from 100 to 15,000 deliveries per month, I learned what systems actually need to work at scale. Now I teach those exact methods - no client work, no distractions, just focused on helping you build automations that don't break."

**About Page:**
"Mechanical engineer turned operations lead turned teacher. I've been through the full journey - building systems, scaling them, and now teaching others to do the same. My Upwork days taught me what businesses actually need. Now you get those lessons without the trial and error."

---

## Rule 3: Always Call Out Who You're Looking For (And Who You're Not)
**Principle:** Polarize to magnetize the right people.

### Examples for AI Automation:

**Ad Copy:**
"This is for business owners drowning in manual tasks OR aspiring automation consultants ready to charge $2-5k per system. NOT for people looking for get-rich-quick schemes or 'passive income' fantasies."

**Conversion Page:**
"Perfect if you:
- Spend 10+ hours weekly on repetitive tasks
- Have watched YouTube tutorials but can't connect the dots
- Want to build real systems, not play with ChatGPT prompts

Skip this if you:
- Need results tomorrow (good systems take 7-14 days)
- Want to automate without learning the basics
- Think AI will magically fix a broken business"

**About Page:**
"I work with two types of people: Business owners who know their time is worth more than $50/hour, and future automation consultants who want to build $5k systems, not $50 Fiverr gigs."

---

## Rule 4: Always Have a Reason Why
**Principle:** People need a "because" - even a simple one increases action.

### Examples for AI Automation:

**Ad Copy:**
"Launching new templates this month because three members asked for the same system last week. When patterns emerge, we build solutions."

**Conversion Page:**
"Why copy-paste templates? Because after 350+ hours on Upwork, I noticed everyone was building the same 12 automations. So I documented them perfectly. Once."

**Email:**
"Running this workshop because January is when businesses set their efficiency goals. Perfect timing to show you what's possible."

---

## Rule 5: Damaging Admissions
**Principle:** Admit flaws to gain trust, then pivot to strengths.

### Examples for AI Automation:

**Ad Copy:**
"I haven't built million-dollar agencies or sold thousand-dollar courses. I've generated $60k from automations - decent, not extraordinary. But that real-world experience taught me what actually works, which is why 100,000+ people learn from me."

**Conversion Page:**
"Fair warning: This isn't a get-rich-quick program. Most people take 2-3 weeks to build their first working system. But when it runs successfully for the first time, you'll understand why slow and steady beats fast and broken."

**About Page:**
"I don't take client work anymore - teaching takes all my time. But that means every template, every system, every example comes from real projects that had to work. No theory, just battle-tested solutions."

---

## Rule 6: Show Don't Tell
**Principle:** Describe the experience, not the feature.

### Examples for AI Automation:

**Ad Copy:**
Instead of: "Automate your lead generation"
Write: "Monday morning: Your pipeline report is already in Slack. Data pulled from three systems, formatted, and sent. You haven't even opened your laptop yet."

**Conversion Page:**
Instead of: "Save time on reporting"
Write: "That Friday afternoon panic when leadership wants updated numbers? Gone. Your dashboard refreshes itself every morning at 7 AM. You just screenshot and send."

**About Page:**
Instead of: "I scaled operations efficiently"
Write: "I still remember the Monday we processed 1,000 orders before lunch. The same volume that used to take us all week. That's when I knew systems were everything."

---

## Rule 7: Tie Benefits to Status
**Principle:** Show how this elevates their position among peers.

### Examples for AI Automation:

**Ad Copy:**
"When ops teams ask how you 'suddenly have all this time for strategy,' you'll know the automations are working."

**Conversion Page:**
"Imagine your next leadership meeting: 'We've reduced manual processing by 80%.' Watch your CFO's face when you show the time savings in actual dollars."

**For Aspiring Consultants:**
"Quote $5,000 for a two-day build while others scramble for $500 projects. Because you have templates that actually work."

---

## Rule 8: Use Urgency and Scarcity
**Principle:** Create legitimate reasons to act now.

### Examples for AI Automation:

**Legitimate Scarcity:**
"I only onboard 20 new members monthly because each gets a 1-on-1 implementation call. December spots: 7 left."

**Legitimate Urgency:**
"Template access increases to $497 on January 1st. (We're adding 3 new systems and current members get grandfathered at $197)"

**Course Launch:**
"Live implementation week starts Monday. Miss it, and you're building alone until next quarter."

---

## Rule 9: Implied Authority
**Principle:** Let credentials and proof speak to expertise.

### Examples for AI Automation:

**Ad Copy:**
"Join 100,000+ who've learned automation from someone Udemy rated 4.6/5 stars across 3,000+ students."

**Conversion Page:**
"Top 3% Upwork performer. 100% job success. 350+ hours. Built systems processing millions in revenue."

**About Page:**
"Mechanical Engineering degree (built things) → Scaled startup 150x (managed things) → Teaching automation (simplifying things)."

---

## Rule 10: Always Have a P.S. Statement
**Principle:** The P.S. is the second-most read part of any copy.

### Examples for AI Automation:

**Email P.S.:**
"P.S. - The free course covers 80% of what you need. The paid program is for people who want to go from 'it works' to 'it scales.'"

**Sales Page P.S.:**
"P.S. - If you're thinking 'this is too complex for me,' remember: I teach mechanical engineers AND complete beginners. Same success rate."

**About Page P.S.:**
"P.S. - Everything I teach comes from real projects that had to work. No theory, just solutions."

---

## Rule 11: Clear CTAs (Call-to-Actions)
**Principle:** Tell them exactly what to do next.

### Examples for AI Automation:

**Ad CTA:**
"Not ready to invest? Start with my free course → Learn the fundamentals → See if this is right for you → Then decide"

**Conversion Page CTA:**
"Two paths: Ready to build? Join the full program. Want to test the waters? Grab the free course and see how we teach."

**Email CTA:**
"Take the free course first. If you build one working automation from it, you'll know the paid program will transform your business."

**Bottom of Blog Posts:**
"Next step: Take the free AI Automation fundamentals course. No fluff, just the core concepts you need. Then decide if you want to go deeper."

---

## Rule 12: Third Grade Reading Level
**Principle:** Simple words, short sentences, big results.

### Examples for AI Automation:

**Instead of:** "Leverage artificial intelligence to augment operational efficiency"
**Write:** "Use AI to do boring work faster"

**Instead of:** "Comprehensive automation framework implementation"
**Write:** "Copy our templates. Build working systems. Bill clients."

**Instead of:** "Synthesize disparate data sources"
**Write:** "That report you build every week? Let's automate it."

---

## Bonus Rule: Use Humor (Sparingly)
**Principle:** Light touches of personality without forcing it.

### Examples for AI Automation:

**Ad Copy:**
"My automations aren't pretty. But they run at 3 AM without complaining."

**Email Subject:**
"Your spreadsheet called. It wants a vacation."

**About Page:**
"Yes, I name my automations. No, I'm not sorry."

---

## Quick Implementation Checklist

**Before Publishing Any Copy, Check:**
1. Is the headline strong enough to stop scrolling?
2. Did I mention unique proof (100k taught, Udemy rating, etc.)?
3. Am I clear about who this is (and isn't) for?
4. Do I have a "because" for any ask?
5. Did I admit something real without being self-deprecating?
6. Am I showing the experience, not just telling the feature?
7. Does this elevate their status among peers?
8. Is my urgency/scarcity legitimate?
9. Have I included authority markers naturally?
10. Do I have a strong P.S.?
11. Is my CTA crystal clear with next steps?
12. Can a third-grader understand this?

**Platform-Specific Notes:**
- **Email:** Lead with value, soft CTA to free course
- **Landing Pages:** Problem → Solution → Proof → Free Course CTA
- **Ads:** Hook with results, qualify audience, offer free value first

**Remember:** Your audience values efficiency and hates fluff. Every word should either build trust or drive action. When in doubt, simplify.

# Your Complete Tone of Voice Brief

## Core Voice Characteristics

### 1. **Practical Simplifier**
You take complex problems and make them simple, actionable solutions. You avoid technical jargon and focus on business value people can understand.

### 2. **Collaborative Efficiency Expert** 
You use "we" language and bring people along on the journey while maintaining focus on practical outcomes and fast decision-making.

### 3. **Diplomatic Truth-Teller**
You're honest about challenges and solutions but deliver that honesty in a thoughtful, story-driven way that doesn't alienate.

## Your Voice Profile Summary

**Background:** Corporate-to-startup journey gives you credibility on both slow bureaucracy and fast execution
**Core Drive:** Helping people achieve what they didn't think possible by giving them effective tools
**Sweet Spot:** Solving manual, time-consuming problems that impact daily sanity
**Audience:** No-nonsense, straight-talking professionals who value efficiency
**Approach:** Collaborative educator who breaks down complexity into clear, step-by-step solutions

## Signature Phrases & Language Patterns

### Words/Phrases You Naturally Use:
- "Let's figure this out together"
- "Here's what we can do..."
- "This impacts your day-to-day sanity"
- "Making a huge impact"
- "In business terms..."
- "Fast decision making"
- "Step-by-step approach"
- "Tools that actually work"
- "Cut through the complexity"
- "Practical solution"

### Your "Never" List:
- Over-technical jargon without explanation
- Exaggerated claims or hype language
- Corporate buzzwords like "synergy," "leverage," "paradigm shift"
- Overly aggressive sales language
- Talking about features instead of business value

## Platform-Specific Voice Guidelines

### LinkedIn Posts

**Tone:** Professional but approachable, educational
**Structure:** Problem → Story/Example → Simple Solution → Collaborative call-to-action
**Length:** 150-300 words typically

**Example:**

> 
> I worked with a team recently who were manually updating 15 different spreadsheets every Monday. The process was eating their morning and setting a stressful tone for the week.
> 
> Here's what we did: We connected their systems with a simple automation that updates everything in one click. Total setup time: 2 hours. Time saved weekly: 2.5 hours.
> 
> The real win? They told me their Monday mornings feel completely different now.
> 
> What manual process is draining time from your team's week?

### LinkedIn Comments

**Tone:** Supportive, practical, brief
**Approach:** Add value, share relevant experience, ask thoughtful follow-ups

**Examples:**
> "This resonates. We've seen similar results when teams automate their reporting. The time savings are obvious, but the stress reduction is often the bigger win."

> "Great point about involving the team in the solution design. We've found that when people help build the process, adoption happens naturally."

### Email/Newsletters

**Tone:** Conversational, like talking to a colleague over coffee
**Structure:** Personal touch → practical insight → clear next step

**Example Subject Lines:**
- "The 2-hour fix that saves 10 hours weekly"
- "Why your manual process isn't your fault (but you can fix it)"

>

### Social Media (Twitter/X)

**Tone:** Direct, practical, conversational
**Format:** Clear statement + practical tip or question

**Examples:**
> "Stop building complex workflows. Start with the one manual task that wastes the most time. Fix that first. Then move to the next one."

> "Best advice for choosing automation tools: Pick the one your team will actually use, not the one with the most features."

### Video/Presentation Scripts

**Tone:** Conversational, like explaining to a friend
**Approach:** Use "we" language, include brief stories, focus on practical outcomes

**Example Opening:**
> "Let's talk about something that's probably frustrating your team right now - those manual processes that eat up hours of your week. I want to show you how we can fix this, step by step."

### Sales/Discovery Calls

**Tone:** Consultative, collaborative, genuinely curious
**Approach:** Ask diagnostic questions, share relevant experience, focus on their specific pain

**Example Phrases:**
- "Help me understand how this impacts your day-to-day..."
- "I've seen similar challenges with other teams..."
- "Let's figure out what would make the biggest difference for you..."
- "Here's what we could do together..."

## Content Pillars Based on Your Strengths

### 40% - Practical Solutions
Breaking down complex problems into simple, actionable steps
- "How to automate [specific manual task] in under 2 hours"
- "3 simple tools that eliminate weekly busywork"
- "Step-by-step guide to [specific efficiency improvement]"

### 30% - Educational Content
Making complex topics accessible with business value focus
- "Why automation fails (and how to make it work)"
- "Business case for streamlining [specific process]"
- "What executives need to know about process efficiency"

### 30% - Experience-Based Insights
Stories from your corporate-to-startup journey and client work
- "What I learned about efficiency moving from corporate to startup"
- "How one team saved 15 hours weekly (real example)"
- "The manual process that was secretly costing $50k annually"

## Voice Consistency Checklist

Before publishing any content, ask:
1. **Does this sound like I'm talking to a colleague over coffee?**
2. **Am I using everyday language instead of technical jargon?**
3. **Is the business value clear and specific?**
4. **Does this help someone achieve something they didn't think was possible?**
5. **Am I being honest without being harsh?**
6. **Would a no-nonsense professional find this valuable and straightforward?**

Regra 1: O Título Vem Primeiro
Princípio: O título define se alguém lê o resto. 80% da performance vem dele.

Títulos de Anúncio:
- “Transformei um funil travado em uma máquina previsível — e te mostro o blueprint.”
- “Como reduzimos 60% do custo de aquisição só reorganizando o processo de SDR.”
- “O método que substitui improviso por sistema — e escala vendas mesmo sem mais equipe.”

- “Construa uma operação de vendas que roda sozinha — e gera resultado com menos pressão.”
- “De caótico para previsível: como montar um BPO comercial com inteligência e processo.”

Títulos de Página ‘Sobre’:

- “Sou obcecado por sistemas comerciais que escalam — porque vivi o caos de não tê-los.”

Princípio: Sua prova única é o que ninguém consegue copiar.

Página ‘Sobre’:
 “Arquiteto de Processos Comerciais e Especialista em Escala com IA. Já vi o que funciona — e o que não — em dezenas de negócios. Meu foco hoje é transformar estratégias em sistemas replicáveis que unem pessoas, processos e tecnologia.”
Regra 3: Fale com Quem É (E Quem Não É)
Princípio: Polarize. Quem tenta falar com todos, perde todos.
Anúncio:
 “Feito para quem quer construir operações previsíveis, treinar pessoas com método e escalar sem precisar de mais braços.
 Não é para quem ainda acredita que precisa ‘contratar mais vendedores’ para vender mais.”

Regra 4: Sempre Tenha um “Porque”

Regra 5: Admita Suas Limitações (E Mostre Força Real)
Princípio: Vulnerabilidade estratégica gera confiança.
Anúncio:

Regra 6: Mostre, Não Diga

Exemplo de E-mail:

Regra 11: CTAs Claros

 “Quer sair do improviso e escalar com sistema?
 → Agende uma consultoria gratuita de diagnóstico
 → Entenda seu gargalo
 → Veja se o modelo se aplica à sua operação.”
Regra 12: Clareza é Rei
Exemplo:
 Em vez de “Implementamos frameworks de eficiência operacional em ecossistemas comerciais complexos”
